citations.narrative:
-During inspection it was reported by the facility representative that the four dogs housed outside were yard dogs. There
was a red and white male border collie type dog housed with a golden retriever in one pen and two black and white border
collie females in the adjoining pen. The golden retriever was included on that facilities APHIS form 7005 but the other
three dogs were not. The facility representative reported that the litter of border collies being weaned in the sheltered
facility were the offspring on the red and white male and one of the border collie females. The inspector informed the
facility representative that if dogs are intermingled with facility dogs, producing puppies for the facility or intact and on the
premises they must be accounted for on the APHIS form 7005 for the facility.
-There were APHIS form 7005s filled out for litter of puppies through May of 2024 but records for puppies after May were
not available to the inspector. The cage cards for the puppies did not contain all the information that is on the APHIS form
7005 so all puppies should be recorded on an APHIS form 7005.
Accurate record keeping is crucial for ensuring a thorough inspection and needed to rapidly identify and trace animals in a
potential disease outbreak. Each dealer and/or exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and
correctly disclose the information in 2.75(a)(1)(i) through 2.75(a)(1)(ix) for each dog purchased or otherwise acquired,
owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or
otherwise disposed of by that licensee. The licensee must ensure accurate records are created and maintained for all
dogs at the facility.
Correction Date: September, 13th 2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The water bucket for the two border collies that were housed outside had a coating of green fuzzy slime coating the entire
bucket under the waterline. The self-feeder that was being used for the same two border collies had and interior that was
coated with black gritty material. Upon inspector request, a fresh water bucket was added to the primary enclosure but the
dirty water bucket was not removed.
Failure to clean and sanitize as often as necessary does not protect the dogs from exposure to disease hazards.
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs and cats must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks
using one of the methods prescribed in paragraph (b)(3) of this section, and more often if necessary to prevent an
accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards.
To be corrected by: September, 11 2024

The facility does not currently maintain records of the administration of heartworm preventative medications to adult dogs.
The facility representative reported that he uses ivermectin on the puppies but not often on the adults. The program of
veterinary care states that heartworm preventative should be given every 30 days. Records of these treatments are
needed to facilitate adherence to the program of veterinary care and to minimize risks of parasitism. The facility must
follow the Program of veterinary care and create and maintain individual medical records for all dogs.
Correction date: September 11th, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
-During inspection it was reported by the facility representative that the four dogs housed outside were yard dogs. There 
was a red and white male border collie type dog housed with a golden retriever in one pen and two black and white border 
collie females in the adjoining pen. The golden retriever was included on that facilities APHIS form 7005 but the other 
three dogs were not. The facility representative reported that the litter of border collies being weaned in the sheltered 
facility were the offspring on the red and white male and one of the border collie females. The inspector informed the 
facility representative that if dogs are intermingled with facility dogs, producing puppies for the facility or intact and on the 
premises they must be accounted for on the APHIS form 7005 for the facility.  
-There were APHIS form 7005s filled out for litter of puppies through May of 2024 but records for puppies after May were 
not available to the inspector. The cage cards for the puppies did not contain all the information that is on the APHIS form 
7005 so all puppies should be recorded on an APHIS form 7005.  
Accurate record keeping is crucial for ensuring a thorough inspection and needed to rapidly identify and trace animals in a 
potential disease outbreak. Each dealer and/or exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and 
correctly disclose the information in 2.75(a)(1)(i) through 2.75(a)(1)(ix) for each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, 
owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or 
otherwise disposed of by that licensee. The licensee must ensure accurate records are created and maintained for all 
dogs at the facility. 
Correction Date: September, 13th 2024 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The water bucket for the two border collies that were housed outside had a coating of green fuzzy slime coating the entire 
bucket under the waterline. The self-feeder that was being used for the same two border collies had and interior that was 
coated with black gritty material. Upon inspector request, a fresh water bucket was added to the primary enclosure but the 
dirty water bucket was not removed.  
Failure to clean and sanitize as often as necessary does not protect the dogs from exposure to disease hazards.  
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs and cats must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks 
using one of the methods prescribed in paragraph (b)(3) of this section, and more often if necessary to prevent an

accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. 
To be corrected by: September, 11 2024 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility does not currently maintain records of the administration of heartworm preventative medications to adult dogs. 
The facility representative reported that he uses ivermectin on the puppies but not often on the adults. The program of 
veterinary care states that heartworm preventative should be given every 30 days. Records of these treatments are 
needed to facilitate adherence to the program of veterinary care and to minimize risks of parasitism. The facility must 
follow the Program of veterinary care and create and maintain individual medical records for all dogs. 
Correction date: September 11th, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
